title: 113_s1150
content: The Act may be cited as the "Congressional Tribute to Constance Baker Motley Act of 2013". Constance Baker Motley, born in 1921 in New Haven, Connecticut, was a key figure in the civil rights movement. She graduated from New York University in 1943 and later became a staff attorney at the NAACP Legal Defense and Educational Fund, where she worked alongside Thurgood Marshall to fight against segregation. Motley was the only female attorney on the legal team that won a landmark desegregation case. Constance Baker Motley, part of the LDF legal team that won Brown v. Board of Education, argued major civil rights cases before the Supreme Court, winning all but one. Her only loss was in Swain v. Alabama, later reversed in Batson v. Kentucky. She became the first... In 1964, Constance Baker Motley became the first African-American woman elected to the New York State Senate. In 1965, she became the first African-American woman and the first woman to serve as president of the Borough of Manhattan. As a public official, she fought for civil rights, urban revitalization, and improvement of public schools and housing. In 1966, she was appointed as a judge on the United States District Court for the Southern District of New York by President Lyndon B. Johnson, making her the first African-American woman and the fifth woman appointed for a Federal judgeship. Constance Baker Motley was appointed as a Federal judge in 1966 and became Chief Judge of the United States District Court for the Southern District of New York in 1982. She continued serving on the court until 1986 when she assumed senior status. She passed away in 2005 and is survived by her husband, son, grandchildren, brother, and sisters. Congress authorizes the posthumous presentation of a gold medal to honor Constance Baker Motley for her contributions to the United States. The Secretary of the Treasury will design and strike the medal. Additionally, provisions for duplicate medals are included. The Secretary may strike and sell duplicates of the gold medal in bronze under regulations, at a price covering costs. The medal is considered a national medal, and duplicates are classified as numismatic items. Proceeds from sales can be used as authorized. SEC. 6. AUTHORITY TO USE FUND AMOUNTS; PROCEEDS OF SALE. The United States Mint Public Enterprise Fund can be used to pay for the cost of medals struck under this Act. Amounts from the sale of duplicate bronze medals will be deposited back into the Fund.
